official-title.#text:
To award a Congressional Gold Medal to Sally K. Ride in
		  recognition of her exemplary service as an astronaut, physicist, and science
		  education advocate.

cosponsor.#text:
Ms. Eddie
			 Bernice Johnson of Texas

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Sally K. Ride Congressional Gold Medal
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

On June 18, 1983, as a crew member of the
			 Space Shuttle Challenger STS–7 mission, Dr. Sally K. Ride became the first
			 American woman to travel into space.

Dr. Ride traveled to space on October 5,
			 1984, as a crew member of STS 41–G.

Following the
			 Space Shuttle Challenger disaster in 1986, Dr. Ride served as a member of the
			 Presidential commission investigating the accident.

Dr. Ride also
			 served on the Space Shuttle Columbia Accident Investigation Board in 2003, and
			 was the only person to have served on both the Space Shuttle Challenger and the
			 Space Shuttle Columbia accident investigation boards.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(NASA) astronaut,
			 Dr. Ride was a Ph.D. physicist and served as a professor of physics and the
			 Director of the California Space Institute at the University of California, San
			 Diego.

text.#text:
In addition to her
			 service as a

In 2001, to
			 further her long-time passion of motivating girls and young women to pursue
			 careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, Dr. Ride founded
			 Sally Ride Science, a company that creates entertaining science programs and
			 publications for elementary and middle school students.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the Space Studies
			 Board of the National Research Council.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology

text.#text: Dr. Ride served as a member of the

The exemplary
			 service of Dr. Ride as a NASA astronaut, physicist, and science education
			 advocate inspired a generation of Americans.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, of a gold medal of appropriate design in commemoration of Sally K.
			 Ride in recognition of her exemplary service as an astronaut, physicist, and
			 science education advocate.
